plist.p: Good morning, London, and good afternoon, Hong Kong. And welcome to the Standard Chartered 2009 Annual Results Presentation. I'm delighted to announce that 2009 was the seventh successive year of record income and profits. The Bank has used its strong capital and liquidity position and its increasingly powerful brand to capture market share from competitors and to deepen relationships with customers and clients.

Standard Chartered grew income and profit despite the economic downturn across the world and significant interest rate and FX headwinds. Income increased 9% to $15.2 billion. Profit before tax rose to 13% – rose by 13% to $5.2 billion.
Normalized earnings per share were up 2.8% to $1.798. The board is recommending a final dividend of $0.448 per share, making an annual dividend of $0.6603 per share, which is up by 7%.

Throughout the financial crisis and economic downturn, we've consistently produced strong results. We have achieved this by sticking to our strategy and supporting our customers and clients through these difficult times. Throughout the crisis we stayed open for business.

We helped many of our customers buy their homes, increasing our mortgage lending by $10 billion to a total of $58 billion. In 2009, our total lending to customers, clients and financial institutions increased by $28 billion, an increase of over 10%. The Bank now lends more than $250 billion.

Longevity in our markets is something we are very proud of. Not only does it give us the local knowledge to serve our customers well, it also makes us part of their community. We have been working with many of our clients for generations. And the downturn as uniquely helped us to reinforce these valuable relationships.

We've managed a way through the crisis very well, much to the benefit of clients and shareholders. However, like most bankers, we are conscious that the world has changed, and that we must work together with regulators, governments and the rest of industry to secure a better financial system if we are to support the global recovery, and to focus on the socially useful aspects of banking.

Peter will be saying more about our views on regulation in a moment, but let me first just touch on the bonus issue, which has been so much in the spotlight in recent weeks. In the geographic footprint in which we operate, competition for talented employees is red hot. Today we employ over 75,000 people, only 2,000 of whom are based in the U.K. We must therefore take a global perspective in setting a remuneration policy.

We pay for good performance. We do not reward failure. And we have continued to produce record income and profits on a sustained basis. We have increased our capital base, raised our dividend, continue to invest in the business and have generated substantial value for our shareholders over an extended period of time.

We have not used government liquidity, capital or asset protection support. On balance, the board has therefore concluded that it is in the interests of the business and our shareholders to reward the management team for yet another successful year and to retain top talent in these fiercely competitive markets, but only when it is appropriate to do so.

We are also satisfied that our remuneration policies encourage long-term performance and do not reward short-term risk-taking. We fully support the FSA code on remuneration, to which we were already broadly aligned last year, and we have gone still further this year. So we will continue to reward performance within that framework. However, in setting this year's bonus pool we did take into account the U.K. bonus tax and we've spread the cost of this across the business globally. Our compensation as a proportion of revenue has fallen in each of the last two years to 32%.

For all the industry and media discussion on regulation and remuneration, it is crucial that the balance of regulatory reform is right to avoid unintended consequences that could potentially hinder global recovery. The best way to protect against financial stress and ensure an effective, functioning financial system is to have sound, well-managed, well-governed institutions.

At Standard Chartered we do have a proven strategy and a world-class management team, both of which have withstood the test of the last couple of years. We have also taken steps to further strengthen our corporate governance with new appointments to the board and changes to the board committee structure. Mike Rees and Jaspal Bindra have both been appointed Group Executive Directors. Mike has been CEO of Wholesale Banking since 2002. And Jaspal is our CEO in Asia.

We have also appointed three new Non-Executive Director. Dr. Han Seung-soo was Prime Minister of the Republic of Korea in 2008 and 2009. Richard Delbridge has had a wide-ranging banking career. And Simon Lowth is currently an Executive Director and Chief Financial Officer of AstraZeneca Plc.

I would also like to take this opportunity to publicly thank Gareth Bullock, another of our Group Executive Directors, for the significant contribution he has made to the success of the Bank over many years. Gareth will be stepping down from the board on the 30th of April.

In 2009 the board conducted a review and implemented changes to the board committee structures to reinforce the high standards of corporate governance. This included separating the existing Audit and Risk Committees to accentuate the focus on risk management.

So in summary, 2009 was another successful year for the Bank. We faced challenges in the global economic and regulatory environment, but the board believes Standard Chartered has the right strategy for sustainable growth and the Bank enters 2010 with real resilience and momentum.

I'll now hand over to Richard who will take you through the numbers. Peter will then address some of the macro issues across our markets and our strategic priorities. We'll then take questions. Richard?
Thank you, John. Good afternoon, Hong Kong. Good morning, London. As John has said, Standard Chartered has delivered another record performance in 2009 and let me draw out several key highlights.

Record levels of income, over $15 billion, and record levels of profit, over $5.1 billion. 2009 was the seventh consecutive year of record income and profit, delivering compound annual growth rates of 19% in income and 22% in profit over that period.
Substantial income momentum. The Group has generated in excess of $1 billion of incremental organic income. Income on a reported basis is up 9% year-on-year, or on a constant currency basis, up 14%.

Demonstrable cost control. Costs are well controlled, up 4% on 2008 delivering positive jaws. A proactive approach to risk. The risk environment is improving as reflected in improvement in leading risk indicators and total impairment has fallen in the second half.

Strong profit growth of $583 million, up 13%, or on a constant currency basis, up 18%. Ongoing capital strength. We have generated organic Core Tier 1 equity of $3.2 billion and raised $1.7 billion through an equity placing. We have managed risk-weighted assets well, growing by 13%. The Core Tier 1 ratio grew to 8.9%, up from 6.1% only 18 months ago.

Liquidity. We have further strengthened our robust liquidity position, attracting good levels and an improving mix of high-quality deposits. Our A/D ratio remains very strong at 78.6%. Normalized return on equity of 14.3%.
These are excellent results and even more so given the low interest rate environment and the impact of foreign exchange headwinds. Now let me take you through the numbers.

Group performance. At a Group level, income has grown 9% driven by excellent momentum in Wholesale Banking, but also a consistent quarter-on-quarter improvement in performance in Consumer Banking. Expenses are benefiting from strong management discipline and have grown 4%, resulting in positive jaws of 5%.
Loan impairment, although up 51% year-on-year, was down 16% or some $180 million in the second half over the first half. Operating profit of $5.15 billion was up 13%.

Turning to performance metrics. Dividend per share has grown 7%. Normalized EPS has risen 3% and includes the impact of the rights issue and the placing but also, as mentioned at the time of the interim results, a higher year-on-year effective tax rate.

Normalized EPS excludes four main items: the impact of the buyback of Tier 2 notes of $264 million; the provision of $170 million taken against structured notes issued by PEM Group in Taiwan; a one-off tax charge relating to the finalization of prior year U.K. tax computations of $190 million; and $58 million in relation to the U.K. bank bonus tax.

Balance sheet. The balance sheet continues to be conservatively positioned, well diversified and highly liquid. The Group remains strongly liquid both in parts and as a whole, with a diverse and growing funding base.

Current accounts and savings accounts, or CASA, grew by 34% or some $40 billion, with time deposits falling $11 billion since 2008. We have focused on improving the mix of our deposit base and the proportion of CASA has increased to 53% of total Group deposits from 43% at the end of 2008.

Wholesale continues to win significant cash mandates across a variety of markets. And Consumer is a high-quality deposit-gatherer, providing further resilience to the Group. Total Group deposits increased 8%.

Our focus on liabilities and disciplined deployment of the balance sheet has again resulted in a strong ratio of customer loans to customer deposits, the A/D ratio, which end 2009 stood at 78.6%. The A/D ratio in all of our major geographies is under 100%. The Group remains a strong net interbank lender and the liquidity ratio has strengthened significantly to 26.2%.

Turning to assets. Our loan book is well diversified by country and by sector. Our balance sheet remains as before a source of differentiation and strength for the Group. We have low loan-to-values on our mortgage book, with an average of just over 50%. Short maturity profile on our Wholesale loan book with around 70% of the book under one year.

Our ABS carrying value is now just under $3 billion, or some 0.7% of assets, and we remain confident in the quality of the portfolio. We have low exposure to commercial real estate, to level 3 assets and to leveraged loans.

Overall exposures are diversified over geography and sector with no material concentrations. Our largest individual geography accounts for 18% of total Group loans. Cover ratios have strengthened in both businesses, which positions us well as we enter 2010. The balance sheet remains robust and well diversified.

Capital. The Group's strong capital position continues to improve as we organically generated some $3.2 billion of Core Tier 1 equity and we are proactively improving both the quantum and quality of capital. As you will recall we also raised $1.7 billion in an equity placing in August. Throughout the year we have had good support from capital markets through our funding and non-equity Tier 1 issuances.

As a bank, within our funding profile, we have very low levels of refinancing maturing over the next few years, only some $8 billion until the end of 2013. And this will be increasingly important given the massive refinancing needs for the European, and in particular the U.K., banking sector. Core Tier 1 is up at 8.9%, total Tier 1 is at 11.5% and total capital is at 16.5%. We are very well capitalized, especially in light of our conservative balance sheet asset profile.

Now the Consumer Banking performance. The repositioning of the Consumer Banking business is progressing well, as evidenced by a range of financial and non-financial metrics. The business has good momentum as we exit 2009 and an improving risk picture.

For the full year Consumer Banking income fell 5% and expenses fell 3% with operating profit before tax down 22% to $867 million. Momentum in the second half of 2009 has, however, been good and profit in the second half of the year was up 49% on the first half.

Consumer Banking has seen good balance sheet velocity for both assets and liabilities. Loans have grown 17%, primarily in secured product as we have taken good market share in a number of key markets. And deposits grew 11%. The percentage of new CASA that comes from payroll accounts has doubled year-on-year. And Consumer Banking is contributing some $35 billion of surplus liquidity to the Group. Looking at Consumer Banking in more detail.

Consumer Banking income has grown by 10% in the second half of the year over the first. Quarterly income has now risen for four quarters in succession. The business has faced two specific structural headwinds in 2009, being liability margin compression of some 60 basis points and also foreign exchange weakness. Together these two factors have impacted income by some $1 billion, in part offset by good volume growth but also by asset margins holding up well.

Expenses have fallen in Consumer Banking by 3% year-on-year and, excluding the impact of PEM Group, actually fell by 8%. We have maintained cost discipline, reducing head count by around 3,000 since the end of 2008. And we're seeing increasing efficiencies as a result of hubbing, call center rationalization and standardization of processes.

In the second half of the year, expenses grew 8% over the first half as we accelerated the level of new investment to some $60 million in the fourth quarter, specifically to underpin our 2010 momentum. During the year we added relationship managers in premium banking, private banking, and in SME. We added 79 new branches whilst relocating and refurbishing over 130 branches, invested in Internet and mobile banking and we increased marketing spend.

The Consumer Banking loan impairment charge has increased to $1,052 million, up 12% on 2008. Loan impairment in the second half of the year fell 13% on the first half as the credit environment stabilized.

We've continued to focus on secured assets. 76% of the loan book is fully secured, 8% is partially secured, and 60% is unsecured. We've tightened our underwriting standards, reshaped the unsecured business away from high-risk segments, increased collections capacity by 10% and migrated towards government-guaranteed loans in the SME business.

Looking at income in more detail, wealth management fee income has grown quarter-on-quarter during the year. Fourth quarter fee income was up over 35% on the first quarter, reflecting improving sentiment and increasing sales of fund products in our key markets. Singapore and Taiwan performed particularly well. Wealth management including deposits is down from 47% of total Consumer Banking income in 2008 to 40% in 2009.

Mortgages have performed well with good margins and market shares up in Hong Kong, in Korea and in Singapore. In Singapore, we captured 15% of new business in the year and in Hong Kong we captured 17%.

SME income fell 12% year-on-year, although income in the second half of the year was up by 12% on the first half. Deposits in SME are around twice the level of loan balances and grew 21%. Loans grew 14% to $13.3 billion. The SME business has been reshaped and derisked with increasing focus on secured lending and increased use of government-guarantee schemes. Around 60% of the SME book is secured.

Impairment. Now let me draw out the key points on this slide. Looking at mortgages, loan impartment has fallen in the second half of the year. Delinquency trends in our largest markets remained broadly stable. Within SME, you can see that impairment has decreased significantly since the first half of the year. Almost $2 billion of SME loans are now booked under government-guarantee schemes and we have continued to decrease the size of the unsecured business installment loan portfolio.

Credit cards and personal loans contribute some $14 billion of the total $24 billion of other loans. The vast majority of the $761 million loan impairment in other loans was driven by this unsecured portfolio, although loss rates have stabilized since the first two quarters of the year and lead indicators are falling. Other loans also includes secured private bank and wealth management lending, where loss rates are negligible.

As you can see, loan impairment in the fourth quarter of the year fell, as we expected, by some tens of million of dollars on the third quarter. The risk environment in January has continued to improve and we expect the first quarter to continue, if not accelerate, the trend of incremental quarterly improvement.

To summarize for Consumer Banking overall, steady income momentum quarter-on-quarter built on good footings growth, with assets showing an increased bias towards secured and liability showing an improved mix, strong cost discipline allowing for targeted investment, loan impairment showing clear improvement and a robust cover ratio of 84%.

Turning to Wholesale Banking. Through whichever lens you look, Wholesale Banking has had another excellent year in 2009, delivering broad-based and diverse top-line growth across multiple products, geographies and segments. The continuing execution of a consistent and clear strategy, increased depth of client relationships, leverage of the network and firm management of capital liquidity and risk have been key enablers of growth and a differentiating competitive factor.

Wholesale Banking operating profit grew 36% on income that grew 24%. Expenses rose 11% primarily reflecting increased levels of profit-related remuneration and the flow through of investments. Cost growth remains well below income growth, delivering strongly positive jaws of 13%.

Impairment has increased year-on-year but has fallen in the second half of the year. We continue to be disciplined in managing the relationship between risk-weighted assets and income growth. Risk-weighted assets grew by 18%, or some $24 billion, during 2009.

Income. Client income, the major engine of Wholesale Banking revenues, grew strongly, up 22%, and contributes 74% of total Wholesale Banking income. Although client income held up well in the second half of 2009, own-account income fell 47% as spreads returned to more normal levels, volatility decreased and ALM income fell, as we said it would, by some $150 million.

Three of our four client segments each generated income of over $2 billion in 2009 for the first time, with global corporates in particular performing strongly, up 42%. The fourth segment, commodities, grew 38%.

Looking through the product lens. Lending and portfolio management income grew 54%. Transaction banking however fell 5%. Within transaction banking, trade income was up 26% with rising margins ahead of falling volumes whilst we still gained market share.

Cash and custody income was down 24% despite balances increasing 21% to $97 billion. Global markets achieved an excellent 38% growth with strong growth across a broad range of products but in particular in financial markets and in corporate finance.

Looking at income in more detail. During the course of 2009 client income increased its share of total income from 69% in the first half to 80% in the second half of the year, as own-account income softened and client income remained firm. It is worth reiterating that we do not organize ourselves around proprietary activity and we have no proprietary trading desks.

We continue to become more important to our clients and to deepen relationships. Effective collaboration across our network is a powerful competitive advantage, with over 35% of Wholesale Banking client income generated offshore. Commercial banking and flow FX continue to be the pivot of Wholesale Banking, contributing 59% of total client income in 2009.

Lending income was up strongly from $551 million to $849 million, reflecting significantly increased margins, which have largely sustained into the end of the year, and good fee income. Lending volumes increased 3%.

In trade, margins were up by some 70 basis points during the year and we benefited from increasing market share in many geographies. Cash had a very strong increase in volume, although this was insufficient to compensate for margin compression of some 80 basis points, a material drag of some $600 million to income. This is equivalent in magnitude to the impact of liability margin compression in the consumer banking business.
Global markets had an excellent year and remains a predominantly client-driven business. Financial markets is the largest component of global markets and I will talk about this on the next slide.

ALM income was up 6% on 2008. ALM entered the year with strong existing positions, capturing both high fixed interest rates and wide credit spreads, and benefited from lower funding costs as interest rates fell faster than the market expected.

During the year, relatively steep yield curves offered good reinvestment opportunities, resulting in a good robust year for the ALM business. ALM has started 2010 well, and should remain strong through the first half of the year, although this is dependant on yield curves and rates.

Corporate finance income of $1,294 million, which includes advisory, project and export finance, structured trade finance and leverage finance, was up 74% and is the result of extensive investment in people, products and geographic coverage. As we enter 2010, pipelines remain very strong.

Our principal finance business has a strong track record. Income of $337 million was up 33% as investor sentiment improved, especially in the second half. This is a business that we continue to grow selectively. Reinvestments exceed realizations. We have historically exited investments at some three times invested cost.

Looking at financial markets in more detail. Income in financial markets increased 40% to over $3.3 billion, with 69% of this being client income. During 2009 there was a marked difference in performance between the two halves. In the first half of the year, clients were proactive in hedging their risks, bid-offer spreads widened and volatility increased.

In the second half of the year, market conditions were less volatile and bid-offer spreads contracted, resulting in income falling 37% half-on-half. In the fourth quarter income fell on the third quarter primarily in own account, but has rebounded strongly in January.

FX income was up 13% year-on-year as we outperformed the market and took share. Rates increased 18% as we expanded the product suite. And credit income increased significantly on the back of strong client flows and increased volatility.

Income in commodities and equities increased from $141 million to $389 million, reflecting commodity price volatility, expanded geographic and product coverage, and good equities deal flow. Capital markets, where income increased over 70% from $234 million to $409 million, saw good levels of origination, especially in local currency bonds and loans.

Turing to loan impairment. Wholesale Banking loan impairment was a net charge of $948 million, up from $384 million, and there are four particular factors. Firstly and materially, significant impairment was taken, mainly in the first half, against certain local corporate exposures in the Middle East region.

The second factor is specific derivative-related impairments of some $200 million, primarily in Asia. Thirdly, we have increased the portfolio provision by some $150 million of which over 90% was taken in the Middle East and within that, predominantly aimed at the UAE.

Fourthly, across the book the overall portfolio continues to perform resiliently with early alerts down by some 35% from the peak levels seen in March. We are seeing a series of individual small loan impairments but with no particular geographic or industry concentration.

The overall quality of the portfolio has improved during the second half. We do continue to watch the Middle East closely, particularly the UAE, given event at the end of 2009. The Wholesale Banking cover ration of 65% is up on both the half year and on the 2008 year end positions and is, after collateral, a prudent reflection of risk. There's been no appreciable increase in non-performing loans in the second half of the year. The uncovered non-performing loans are well within our historical recovery levels.

Let me summarize the overall Wholesale Banking picture. Wholesale Banking has again delivered another strong set of results with record levels of income from multiple sources, a firm grip on costs and focused management of risk. It enters 2010 with very robust transaction pipelines and strong client income-led momentum with good growth in customer assets and in cash balances.

Now turning to geographic performance, rather than going through each individual geography, I will focus on three in particular, the Middle East and South Asia business, India and Korea. Firstly MESA. Income in MESA grew strongly, driven by the Wholesale Banking business, to just over $2 billion. Of this, some $1 billion of income is in the UAE, our largest geography in the region.

The risk environment in the Middle East has been very much in focus during 2009 and loan impairment increased sufficiently to $811 million. Within the $811 million there are three main drivers. Firstly, as I have mentioned, impairment taken mainly in the first half against a couple of local corporate exposures in the Middle East of some $350 million.

Secondly, $285 million of impairment in the Consumer Banking business, predominantly against the unsecured business. Of this $171 million relates to the UAE. A portfolio provision charge totaling $138 million in the Wholesale Banking business. And we now carry $170 million on the balance sheet, the Wholesale portfolio impairment provision in MESA.

Turning to the shape of the portfolios. The Wholesale Banking loan portfolio in MESA is $14.6 billion. $10 billion is in the UAE and within this $10 billion, our exposure to those high profile Dubai entities currently perceived as troubled is around $500 million. We are fully engaged in the resolution process relating to these entities, and to the extent that we may ultimately take any losses here, we do not expect them to be material.

For Consumer Banking total loans in MESA are $4 billion of which just under $2 billion is in the UAE, with around 60% secured. It's been a tough year. We've taken loan impairment of $171 million. Non-performing loans in the UAE have fallen in the second half and our leading indicators are showing improvement.

India. India has had a truly excellent performance with Wholesale Banking being the primary engine of growth. Total income was $1.8 billion and India became only the second geography to generate in excess of $1 billion of profit. In 2008 income included a $146 million gain on the sale of the asset management company.

Income in Consumer Banking fell 8% headline, although adjusting for the impact of FX, income grew 1%. Income in Wholesale Banking grew 29% headline, or 43% excluding the impact of foreign exchange. This is a diverse business where we have over 150 clients from each of whom we generate more than $1 million in income. It is also a business that has no substantial own-account element, with over 90% of income being client income.

In late 2008 and early 2009 we repriced lending and trade business. And at the same time we continued to win good market share. The strong income pick up from trade and lending more than offset the 100 basis point compression in cash management margins. We also saw a very strong growth in corporate finance where income almost doubled year-on-year as we built out our product set and deepened existing relationships.

Expenses in India as a whole were tightly managed. Loan impairment in India increased by 51%, primarily in Consumer Banking where we saw pressure on unsecured loans. Loss rates have been improving since April and are meaningfully better than the market average.

Korea. We are making good progress in Korea. Income was flat on a headline basis, although increased 16% excluding the impact of foreign exchange. Wholesale had another good year with further momentum. Income was up 22% on a constant currency basis. Client income was 80% of the total and grew over 40%.

Offshore income generated by Korea doubled to over $150 million. Investment and cost growth remained tightly managed and loan impairment returned to more normalized levels as the size of the knock-in, knock-out options, or KIKOs issue, decreases.

Consumer Banking had a solid year despite significant headwinds. Income grew 13% on a constant currency basis. In the second half we've realized around $70 million relating to the sale of our stake in BC Cards. Excluding this, and also on a constant currency basis, income was up some 7% in the second half of the year over the first half.

We've continued to invest in the branch network but expenses have been well controlled and jaws have been neutral. We saw loan impairment pressure on the unsecured loan books in the first half of the year but derisked SME and moved to a more secured footing. We have seen good balance sheet growth in mortgages and the business has steady momentum going into 2010.

Turning then to outlook. 2010 has started well for both businesses. For the Group as a whole, income and profit are higher than in January 2009, and you will recall that we started very fast in 2009. What is particularly pleasing about the performance in January 2010 is the better balance between the two businesses, with Consumer Banking a larger relative contributor to total income and to profit, and also that client income in Wholesale is up strongly.
In Consumer Banking income momentum continues and is ahead of the underlying run rate for the second half of 2009. Expenses remain well managed and the loan impairment picture continues to improve.

The momentum in Wholesale Banking has continued. Client income had a record month in January and was some 80% of total Wholesale Banking income in the month. Own-account income, although lower than in January 2009, was ahead of the run rate for the second half of 2009. And our deal pipelines remain both active and strong.

This said, we remain watchful on the outlook and we are not complacent as to the risk environment. The world remains very uncertain but we enter the year with good momentum. 2010 has started strongly.

We will remain focused on the effective management of capital, on maintaining excellent levels of liquidity, on improving our risk profile further, and on the disciplined execution of our strategy. We are well positioned in growth markets. We are taking market share in multiple products across multiple geographies and we are in great shape.
Thank you. And now I'll hand over to Peter.

Thank you, Richard. Good morning, those of you in London, and good morning to – good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong. Richard has explained the numbers and once again they tell a compelling story. Record profits on the back of record income, another stronger balance sheet, a broader, deeper client and customer franchise. The Bank is in very good shape.

We did not let the crisis interrupt our track record of consistently delivering for our shareholders. We have no intention of allowing the aftermath to deflect us either. Both businesses have begun 2010 with good momentum. And whilst the economic uncertainties remain daunting and the regulatory rules of the game are in a state of total flux, we start the year with a blend of caution and confidence.

And let's be clear, at no point during the crisis did we take capital from any government or liquidity support from any central bank, nor did we utilize debt-guarantee schemes or asset-protection arrangements. But rather than talk about our achievements in 2009, I want to start by talking about the problems or headwinds we faced and the challenges we see ahead. I'll then lay out our strategic priorities for 2010.

At the interims I mentioned three specific challenges we faced in the first half: our overall performance in Korea; loan impairment in Middle East South Asia, MESA; and the sharp fall in income in wealth management and deposits in Consumer Banking.

Richard has already touched on all three issues but to recap, Korea has delivered much better performance in the second half of 2009 and we expect even stronger results in 2010. In MESA, we do anticipate continued challenges, given the political insecurity situation in Pakistan, the well-publicized problems in Dubai, credit issues elsewhere in the region.

However, it is important to keep these issues in perspective. As Richard pointed out, we are well provisioned, we have limited exposure to commercial real estate and the underlying business is strong. Income in MESA was up 25% in 2009, so while not underestimating the near-term challenges, we remain fully committed to the region and are investing for growth. We plan on opening for business in both Saudi Arabia and Libya this year.

In wealth management and deposits the picture is mixed. We saw a marked improvement in wealth management income in the last quarter 2009. Deposit margins remain under pressure, although we have continued to be very successful in attracting accounts and balances.

Now if those were the challenges we saw in the first half, in the second half the biggest challenge to the Bank's overall performance arose from the slowdown in Wholesale Banking's own-account income, which fell 47%. Some of this decline is seasonal since August and December are always slow trading months. But we also felt the effects of reduced bid-offer spreads, lower volatility, reduced ALM opportunities.

Yet to be frank, we're not that worried about this slowdown as we have always said the real engine of growth in Wholesale Banking is client income. Own-account income will fluctuate between 15 and 30% of total income, depending on external factors. It was at the top end of this spectrum in the first half and has now fallen to more normal levels.

Client income momentum is the fundamental driver of Wholesale Banking's performance on a sustainable basis and this continued to be resilient through the second half. Furthermore, client income in January was up over 20% compared to January last year.

So if Korea, MESA, wealth management and deposits and own account in Wholesale Banking posed the biggest challenges in 2009, where do we see the major challenges in 2010? Fundamentally our most significant challenges have less to do with specific markets and more to do with the uncertainties about global economic prospects and the sheer scale and pace of change in banking regulation.

Let me say a bit about both, starting with the global economy. There's no doubt that the global economy starts 2010 looking better then it did 12 months ago. After a contraction of nearly 2% in 2009, global growth will return in 2010. We expect a modest recovery of perhaps 2% or just over this year. However as these figures show, there is a sharp disparity between the prospects for our markets and those for Western economies.

But if we've learned anything from this crisis, it's that the global economy is far less predictable, far more turbulent than many thought. I see five risks. First, remarkably little progress appears to have been made in rebalancing the world economy. And while imbalances of such scale exist, so there remains the potential for currency crisis, asset bubbles and trade wars.

Second, there's a lot of deleveraging still to happen, particularly in the West, both in the private and the public sector and this is never quick or painless. Third, it's far from clear how robust the recovery will be once governments and central banks withdraw their extraordinary stimulus measures.

Fourth, there's a real risk that persistently high levels of unemployment across many parts of the world will fuel protectionism and other populist policies that'll actually impede resumption of sustainable growth. And finally, there's the risk that the pendulum swings too far in the form of banking regulation, with the result that the real economy is starved of credit just as confidence and the desire to invest begins to return.

Our markets, and particularly Asia, are better placed than most part of the world to weather these risks. But they are not immune, so we cannot be complacent. Yet thus far policymakers in most parts of Asia have been remarkably effective in responding to the twists and turns of the crisis. The regulatory debate revolves around how to achieve two important objectives. First, making the banking system safer, less prone to crisis. And second, ensuring we have an efficient and effective banking system that can support recovery and job creation in the real economy.

The challenge is that there are some real trade-offs between these objectives and it's crucial that policymakers strike the right balance. Get it wrong one way and we'll risk another crisis. Get it wrong the other and we'll stifle growth and job creation and risk another sort of crisis.

The debate around capital levels illustrates the point. There's no doubt that the banking system held too little high-quality capital before the crisis. Most banks, including Standard Chartered, have already improved their capital ratios significantly. The question now is, how much is enough? And the closer a regulator was to the epicenter of the crisis, the higher the answer they tend to give.

It's all too easy to see how the pendulum could swing too far, with hugely damaging unintended consequences. And when I say damaging, I don't mean to banks, I mean to the real economy and to jobs. That's why it's absolutely critical that we think through the aggregate impact of all these changes on the real economy before we rush to implement them. This is not to say we are against all the proposals or that we're defending the status quo. Better regulation is clearly needed and we are broadly supportive of many of the specific proposals put forward by the Basel Committee.

Specific measures we do support include: higher capital levels and a greater emphasis on quality of capital, and thus on core equity, with a consistent approach to deductions; a new approach to non-equity capital that allows greater loss absorption in practice; significant increases in the risk-weighting of trading book activities; far more robust liquidity regulation; simplification of resolution approaches, particularly cross-border, to reduce the too-big-to-fail problem; harmonization of accounting approaches; international application of common principles on remuneration; introduction of macro prudential tools such as loan-to-value caps, LTV caps, or liquid asset reserves. Here the West could learn much from Asia, where many of these tools are already well established.

The point is that there is a lot that we agree it makes sense to change and we are committed to working with policy-makers to ensure these changes are as well thought through and practical as possible. But I would also add that there are some things we think are bad ideas. For example, variants of Glass-Steagall seem to us hugely distracting, costly and unlikely to make anyone or anything safer. Pre-funded resolution funds seem equally unattractive since they institutionalize moral hazard. Contingent capital looks remarkably like some of the overly-complex derivatives that helped cause the crisis in the first place and which didn't work in practice the way they were supposed to in theory.

So I would argue for action but deliberate, somewhat cautious action, for simplicity, because complexity creates obscurity and diverts attention from the real risks, and for international consistency, because otherwise we'll stimulate arbitrage and generate yet further complexity. We should also accept that, however good the rules, they won't make up for poor management or poor supervision. And to my mind the crisis had less to do with weaknesses in the regulatory framework, although there were flaws and gaps, than with poor management and governance and with inadequate supervision of existing rules.

Given such economic uncertainties and regulatory flux, it's critically important to be clear on our strategy and priorities. We are. We have a consistent, clear strategy, well understood by staff, customers and investors. Back in 2003 we said we wanted to be the world's best international bank, leading the way in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. Last year we reflected on our strategy, asking ourselves whether or not we should change it in the light of the crisis. Should we expand in the West? Should we be more acquisition-driven?

But we concluded that the fundamentals of our strategy, organically led, focused on Asia, Africa and the Middle East, with a balance sheet-driven, conservative business model, running ourselves as one bank. But these fundamentals are, if anything, even more compelling today than they were before the crisis.

One of the strengths of this strategy is that year after year we have been able to take problems or headwinds in our stride and still deliver superior performance. The geographic pattern of our results demonstrates this resilience and diversity. In 2009, India, Singapore and Africa set the pace once again. U.K., Europe and Americas bounced back strongly. Hong Kong and Other APR returned to good profit growth.

Let me touch on some of the highlights. To start with, India. Hong Kong became the first of our markets to achieve $1 billion in profits in 2007. India achieved this milestone in 2009 and is now just a whisker behind Hong Kong. As you can imagine, there's quite a race for which will be our biggest market by profits this year. We have built a superb franchise in India and this year it is our intention to open a new chapter in our long history by listing in India.

Africa. Profits up 54% to $482 million, an outstanding performance. We're capitalizing on the rapid growth in trade and investment flows between Africa and Asia. Singapore, up 17%, driven by Wholesale Banking. Within Other APR, China, with profits up more than 200% to $280 million, on the back of income up 17%, China is now becoming a significant business for us.

U.K., Europe and Americas, this profit delta of $294 million is driven by a number of factors, including the successful integration of American Express Bank, where we have exceeded our synergy targets, and non-recurrence of the write-downs of strategic investments and ABS and derivative losses we experienced in 2008. The breadth of our business across diverse, fast-growing markets gives us enormous resilience in a turbulent world.

Our near-term strategic priorities are very clear. Our top priority is to maintain our track record of delivering superior financial performance. To do this we need to sustain the momentum in Wholesale Banking and complete the transformation of Consumer Banking. We need to stay absolutely focused on the basics of banking, on the way we manage liquidity, capital, risks and costs. And we also need to grasp the opportunity to reinforce our brand.

The key to sustaining performance momentum in Wholesale Banking is our client franchise. We turned the crisis into an opportunity by reaching out to our clients, filling the gaps that other banks had left. One decision we took following the collapse of Lehman was to take – was to put tight restrictions on taking on new clients. We had prospective clients knocking at every door but we wanted our existing clients to know that at a time of crisis they had first call on our liquidity and capital, that we were there to support them.

In 2009 income from our top 50 clients increased by 38% and the number of clients from which we generated income in excess of $10 million increased by 88%. We are deepening our relationships by getting closer to our clients. We're also expanding the product capabilities and solutions we provide to them. Indeed, we're constantly enhancing these capabilities, both organically and through what we call capability acquisitions.

I've mentioned American Express Bank. I could also have talked about Harrison Lovegrove or First Africa. The most recent was Cazenove's Asian equity businesses, which we purchased last January and now call Standard Chartered Securities. This has already exceeded expectations, executing mandates on a range of IPOs, rights issues and placings, predominantly with existing clients of the Bank. This is the beginning of a deliberate strategy to build a relevant equities business across our key markets, extending our capabilities in helping our clients raise capital and grow.

Whilst Wholesale Banking is constantly refreshing an already highly successful, client-led strategy, Consumer Banking is midway through a strategic transformation. Until recently this was a largely product-led business, but over the last 18 months Steve Bertamini and his team have been reshaping Consumer Banking, so that it too focuses on building deep, longstanding, multi-product relationships with customers. This is a big, complex change program and whilst it is far from complete, we are making good progress.

As Richard has described, Consumer Banking's performance was hit hard by the crisis. Wealth management income collapsed, liability margins fell sharply, loan impairment increased significantly as unemployment rose and small businesses struggled. We moved swiftly and decisively in response, cutting costs, adjusting risk parameters and rebalancing the product mix. But we did not let such tactical priorities deflect us from the strategic reshaping of the business, hiring relationship managers, opening new branches, extending and enhancing mobile and Internet channels, changing incentives and performance metrics, launching a new customer charter.

It's early days in this transformation and we're not fully through the margin headwinds from the crisis, but the signs are more than encouraging. Consumer Banking income in the second half was up 10% on the first half. Despite subdued demand in many of our markets, we're growing the most critical elements of the balance sheet, current and savings accounts, or CASA, up 51%, loans up 17%, faster than ever before. We're winning market share in most products and segments in all of our key markets.

For both businesses, the depth and quality of our client and customer relationships are critical to our strategy and success. And this focus on clients and customers, the obsession with the basics of banking, the emphasis on acting as one bank, on doing the right thing, these are key elements of our culture, key aspects of our brand.

Standard Chartered is a rather different kind of bank. We've been around for more than 150 years. In fact, in 2009 we marked our 150th anniversary in Hong Kong by issuing the world's first $150 note. We believe in building long-term client and customer relationships and without diluting our focus on delivering for shareholders, we are committed to being a force for good in the communities in which we live and work.

There's no doubt that our brand has been strengthened by the way we performed during the crisis. But I think it is still the case that it's the performance of the Bank lifting the brand, rather than the brand helping drive the performance of the Bank. We have a brand that means a lot to those who know us. But too few people in our markets know our name. Too few know what we stand for.

So this year we will be investing to build awareness, not least by putting our name on Liverpool shirts that will be seen on hundreds of millions of television screens around the world. And we will be working harder to tell people what we stand for, what makes us different.

Our brand is all about commitment. We're here for good, to create value for our shareholders, to support and partner our clients and customers and to make a positive contribution to the broader community. We're here for the long term. We don't run when things get tough. We don't dodge tough decisions and trade-offs. This is the way we do business. It has underpinned our strategy and success for over 150 years across Asia, Africa and the Middle East and it will be the foundation for our future.

I became CEO, Chief Executive, in late 2006 just before the world of banking went completely pear-shaped. It probably wasn't the best timing in retrospect. But I am immensely proud of the way the people of Standard Chartered responded to the crisis, turning it into a strategic opportunity for the Bank. So I do want to take this opportunity to thank all of our staff.

I'm also enormously appreciative of the support we received from our clients and customers, from you, our investors, and from our regulators. We look at the crisis as an inflection point. Banking has changed irreversibly. Our role and position in the world of banks has changed dramatically. We didn't just weather the crisis, we turned it to our advantage. Whilst I don't underestimate the challenges and uncertainties before us, I am also excited by the opportunities. We are in the right markets. We have a clear strategy and a strong brand and we've started the year with good momentum.
